awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Toward commercializing cellulose fiber-reinforced polymer composites
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is commercialization of a method of making superior composites with enhanced benefits that are sustainable and environmentally friendly. The new technology could revolutionize the composite industry, especially manufacturing sectors that rely on these materials, such as building, construction, automobiles, and aircraft. Greater use of wood fibers in producing composites also could be a boost to the paper industry by providing an important new use for wood pulp, since cellulose fiber extracted from paper is a raw material for the product of this project. Because the cellulose (or wood) is renewable and based on agricultural products, the composite materials would biodegrade after their service life without harming the environment. The project will impact the demand in the U.S. composites market that is projected to reach over $10 billion by 2019, at a compound annual growth rate of about seven percent, and provide training to the project participants in the process of converting the new technology into a market-ready product.

This I-Corps project addresses a long lasting goal of developing new environmentally friendly and sustainable materials by creating high-performance polymer composites reinforced by natural fibers with superior load-bearing properties. The project involves a new technology that uses natural cellulose (or wood) fibers to reinforce plastic materials. Using cellulose (or wood fibers) in the direct conversion of the polymer building blocks called monomers allows manufacturers to eliminate the melting stage, which is when the materials are shaped, then later solidified into various products. The new processing technology involves taking the wood fibers, usually within paper, and placing them in a mold, then injecting a "reaction" mixture used to make the polymers. The process is down a low relative temperature thus leaving the fibers with their intrinsic structural integrity and mechanical strength and stiffness.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this NSF I-Corps project was to identify the commercialization opportunities and understand the various steps and challenges involved in the commercialization pathway of the novel natural fiber-reinforced engineering thermoplastic composite materials developed at the School of Polymers and High performance Materials of the University of Southern Mississippi. The project provided a better understanding of the current challenges in both the processing limitations of the thermoplastic based composites as well as the real needs in materials and performance aspects currently used in polymer composite industry.  In addition, the project helped us to better direct the ongoing and future research efforts in our lab based on the outcomes of the interactions we had through more than 100 interviews with various potential customers, company decision makers, technical managers, process engineers and the end users in a number of different industry sectors.

One of the most important outcomes of the program was that we were able to identify a customer segment that would be a best fit for our technology and eventually find the “right” value proposition of our technology. Initially we started by looking into construction and sporting goods sectors however; we found that our value propositions didn’t match the customer needs. Therefore, with the help of the industry mentor and the I-Corps teaching team, we narrowed down our customer discovery focus on transportation segment, specifically the automotive and aircraft manufacturing industry. Through the customer interviews, we found that weight reduction of their composite components through our technology which results in enhanced fuel efficiency was of great interest. However, a number of challenges such as process time limitations to maximize production rate, process design flexibility and long technology adoption time of about 5-10 years, were some of the challenges in the commercialization path of the new technology of this project.

The I-Corps program benefited the graduate student who served as the entrepreneurial lead, to better understand the various sections of a business model canvas such as customer relations, supply chain and distribution channels, as well as potential partners and competitors, in addition to improving the interpersonal skills in establishing professional contacts, conducting the customer interviews, and gain an overall better vision of the composite materials industry workflow.     


Last Modified: 03/14/2017
Modified by: Joshua U Otaigbe
